article.paragraph: Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit(IPAc-enˈfærənˌhaɪt;IPA-deˈfaːʀənhaitlang; 24 May 1686 16 September 1736) was a Germanphysicist,engineer, andglass blowerwho is best known for inventing themercury-in-glass thermometer(1714), and for developing aFahrenheittemperature scale now named after him.Encyclopedia Britannica "Science & Technology: Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit"
article.heading: Biography
article.paragraph: Fahrenheit was born in 1686 inGdaskDanzig(Gdask), in thePolish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, but lived most of his life in theDutch Republic. The Fahrenheits were a GermanHansemerchant family who had lived in severalHanseatic LeagueHanseaticcities. Fahrenheit's great-grandfather had lived inRostock, and research suggests that the Fahrenheit family originated inHildesheim.cite bookKant, HorstG. D. Fahrenheit / R. -A. F. de Réaumur / A. Celsius1984B. G. Teubnerhttp://books.google.com/?id14 June 2008Daniel's grandfather moved fromKneiphofinKnigsbergto Danzig and settled there as a merchant in 1650. His son, Daniel Fahrenheit (the father of the subject of this article), married Concordia Schumann, daughter of a well-known Danzig business family. Daniel was the eldest of the five Fahrenheit children (two sons, three daughters) who survived childhood. His sister, Virginia Elizabeth Fahrenheit, married Benjamin Ephraim Krueger of an aristocratic family from Danzig.See theFahrenheit and Krueger genealogies.

Daniel Gabriel began training as a merchant inAmsterdamafter his parents died on 14 August 1701 from eatingAmanita phalloidespoisonous mushrooms. However, Fahrenheit's interest in natural science led him to begin studies and experimentation in that field. From 1717, he traveled toBerlin,Halle, Saxony-AnhaltHalle,Leipzig,Dresden,Copenhagen, and also to his hometown, where his brother still lived. During that time, Fahrenheit met or was in contact withOle Rmer,Christian Wolff (philosopher)Christian Wolff, andGottfried Leibniz. In 1717, Fahrenheit settled inThe Hagueas aglassblower, makingbarometers,altimeters, andthermometers. From 1718 onwards, he lectured inchemistryin Amsterdam. He visited England in 1724 and was the same year elected aFellow of the Royal Society.The Royal Society Archive catalogueFahrenheit died in The Hague and was buried there at theKloosterkerk, The HagueKloosterkerk(Cloister Church).

In 2012, scientists made a computer image of his face using photos of his relatives.cite newsScientists make computer image of inventor's face using photos of his relativesThe Age28 November 2012http://www.theage.com.au/technology/sci-tech/scientists-make-computer-image-of-inventors-face-using-photos-of-his-relatives-20121128-2acjr.html
article.heading: Fahrenheit scale
article.paragraph: File:Fahrenheit Celsius scales.svgthumb80pxThe Celsius and Fahrenheit scalesmainFahrenheitAccording to Fahrenheit's 1724 article,Fahrenheit describes, in Latin, these numerical choices in the following paper:cite journalFahrenheit, D. G.Experimenta et Observationes de Congelatione aquae in vacuo factaePhilosophical Transactions of the Royal Society3378172410.1098/rstl.1724.0016381–391he determined his scale by reference to three fixed points of temperature. The lowest temperature was achieved by preparing afrigorific mixtureofice, water, andammonium chloride(a salt), and waiting for it to reach equilibrium. The thermometer then was placed into the mixture and the liquid in the thermometer allowed to descend to its lowest point. The thermometer's reading there was taken as 0 F. The second reference point was selected as the reading of the thermometer when it was placed in still water when ice was just forming on the surface.cite webhttp://www.physlink.com/Education/AskExperts/ae64.cfm?CFIDWhy does the Fahrenheit scale use 32 degrees as a freezing point?9 May 2008HeathJonathanPhysLinkThis was assigned as 32 F. The third calibration point, taken as 96 F, was selected as the thermometer's reading when the instrument was placed under the arm or in the mouth.

Fahrenheit came up with the idea that mercury boils around 300 degrees on this temperature scale. Work by others showed that water boils about 180 degrees above its freezing point. The Fahrenheit scale later was redefined to make the freezing-to-boiling interval exactly 180 degrees,cite webhttp://www.sizes.com/units/temperature_Fahrenheit.htmFahrenheit temperature scale9 May 200810 December 2006Sizes, Inca convenient value as 180 is ahighly composite number, meaning that it is evenly divisible into many fractions. It is because of the scale's redefinition that normal body temperature today is taken as 98.2 degrees,cite journal10.1001/jama.1992.03490120092034A Critical Appraisal of 98.6°F, the Upper Limit of the Normal Body Temperature, and Other Legacies of Carl Reinhold August Wunderlich1992MacKowiakPhilip A.JAMA: the Journal of the American Medical Association268121578whereas it was 96 degrees on Fahrenheit's original scale.Cite journalElertGlennTemperature of a Healthy Human (Body Temperature)http://hypertextbook.com/facts/LenaWong.shtml4 December 200810.1046/j.1471-6712.2002.00069.x2002Scandinavian Journal of Caring Sciences16122–812000664ForsbergCWahrenLK2

Until the switch to theCelsius scale,whenNovember 2014the Fahrenheit scale was widely used in EuropeCitation neededFebruary 2010. It is still used for everyday temperature measurements by the general population in the United States.For an early attempt to replace the Fahrenheit scale in the United States, seecite bookJohnson, AlbertAbolish the Fahrenheit Thermometer1916Washington, DChttp://books.google.com/?idG.P.O.
